questions.question: What does the camera's drive mode control?
options: How the camera takes shots when you press the shutter (single, burst, timer, etc.)
questions.reviewHint: Drive mode = single, continuous/burst, self-timer, remote, etc.

questions.question: You're photographing fast sports and want multiple frames to catch the peak action. Which drive mode?
questions.reviewHint: Burst fires many frames quickly—great for action.

questions.question: You're on a tripod shooting a slow shutter landscape and want to avoid camera shake when you press the button. Easy option?
questions.reviewHint: A 2s timer lets vibrations settle before the exposure.

questions.question: You're taking a group photo and need time to step into the frame. Which drive mode?
questions.reviewHint: 10s timer gives you time to get in place.

questions.question: A common trade-off when using continuous/burst shooting is:
options: The camera's buffer fills, then shooting slows
questions.reviewHint: Long bursts can fill the buffer → the camera slows while writing.

questions.question: You want the camera to take 3 different exposures in one press (e.g., for HDR later). What feature should you use?
questions.reviewHint: Enable AEB/BKT; many cameras shoot the set in burst or timer.

questions.question: Silent/quiet (electronic) shutter drive is great when you must be discreet. What's a possible downside?
options: Can cause banding under some artificial lights or distort fast motion
questions.reviewHint: Electronic shutters may show banding/rolling-shutter artifacts.

questions.question: You're photographing kids' portraits and want a few frames per moment without flooding the card or buffer. Best choice?
questions.reviewHint: Low-speed burst = several frames, easy on buffer, great for expressions.
